data.title: Catalog
data.meta_description: Jim Carew, a lighthouse keeper, saves New York socialite Ethel Wyndham from drowning after a boating accident, and falls in love as he nurses her back to health. However, she turns down his marriage proposal because of his working-class status. Despondent, Carew aimlessly leaves the East and ends up prospecting in the Yukon. While striking it rich in Alaska, he begins a romance with an Indian woman, Little Snowbird, but before settling down with her, he decides to take one last look at life in the big city, and returns to New York City. At a restaurant there, he sees Ethel, and immediately tells her of his success and proposes once again. Ethel is tempted to accept him until Thomas Martin, who has involved her in a blackmail operation, threatens to expose her if she marries Carew. Once again brokenhearted, and disgusted with her character, Carew returns to Little Snowbird, only to find that, believing that he would never return, the Indian girl has committed suicide just hours earlier.
data.text:
According to the 22 January 1916 Motography, the snowy Alaskan sequences were filmed in the Adirondack Mountains in upstate NY, "where an Alaskan street was constructed, and other Alaskan sets built." A New York City celebration scene was filmed at "the famous Murray's restaurant, near Broadway and Forty-second street....the day after New Years, and all the waiters, omnibuses and the company of professional dancers employed regularly in the restaurant were used."

The 26 February 1916 Motography identified Virtus H. Scott as the assistant director.

Chief White Hawk, "a genuine Sioux chief" from Pine Ridge, SD, made his film debut in The Lure of Heart's Desire, and so impressed star Edmund Breese that the actor put him in his next film, The Spell of the Yukon, the 10 June 1916 Motography noted. Like The Lure of Heart's Desire, The Spell of the Yukon was inspired by a poem written by Robert Service.

The Lure of Heart's Desire was seventeen-year-old actress Betty Riggs' first film under her new name, Evelyn Brent, according to the 5 February 1916 Motion Picture News, which misspelled her last name as "Briggs." Elsewhere in the same issue, an item mentioned that a pack of timber wolves that director Francis J. Grandon took to the Adirondacks for a scene in which they chased Miss Brent's character, "Little Snowbird," scattered after the scene ended and disappeared.

The copyright catalog listed only Aaron Hoffman as the writer, while Movie Picture World also listed Grandon.

This was the third of four 1915-1916 Edmund Breese films taken from Robert ...

More Less

According to the 22 January 1916 Motography, the snowy Alaskan sequences were filmed in the Adirondack Mountains in upstate NY, "where an Alaskan street was constructed, and other Alaskan sets built." A New York City celebration scene was filmed at "the famous Murray's restaurant, near Broadway and Forty-second street....the day after New Years, and all the waiters, omnibuses and the company of professional dancers employed regularly in the restaurant were used."

The 26 February 1916 Motography identified Virtus H. Scott as the assistant director.

Chief White Hawk, "a genuine Sioux chief" from Pine Ridge, SD, made his film debut in The Lure of Heart's Desire, and so impressed star Edmund Breese that the actor put him in his next film, The Spell of the Yukon, the 10 June 1916 Motography noted. Like The Lure of Heart's Desire, The Spell of the Yukon was inspired by a poem written by Robert Service.

The Lure of Heart's Desire was seventeen-year-old actress Betty Riggs' first film under her new name, Evelyn Brent, according to the 5 February 1916 Motion Picture News, which misspelled her last name as "Briggs." Elsewhere in the same issue, an item mentioned that a pack of timber wolves that director Francis J. Grandon took to the Adirondacks for a scene in which they chased Miss Brent's character, "Little Snowbird," scattered after the scene ended and disappeared.

The copyright catalog listed only Aaron Hoffman as the writer, while Movie Picture World also listed Grandon.

This was the third of four 1915-1916 Edmund Breese films taken from Robert W. Service’s poems in The Spell of the Yukon and Other Verses (New York, 1907). The other films were The Shooting of Dan McGrew, The Song of the Wage Slave, and The Spell of the Yukon (see entries).

Metro originally scheduled the film for release on 28 February 1916, according to an advertisement in the 1 January 1916 Moving Picture World, but the 22 January 1916 issues of Motion Picture News and Motography announced that the company had advanced the date forward to 17 February to replace Rose of the Alley (see entry) .

The National Film Preservation Board (NFPB) included this film on its list of Lost U.S. Silent Feature Films as of January 2021.

Less

Jim Carew, a lighthouse keeper, saves New York socialite Ethel Wyndham from drowning after a boating accident, and falls in love as he nurses her back to health. However, she turns down his marriage proposal because of his working-class status. Despondent, Carew aimlessly leaves the East and ends up prospecting in the Yukon. While striking it rich in Alaska, he begins a romance with an Indian woman, Little Snowbird, but before settling down with her, he decides to take one last look at life in the big city, and returns to New York City. At a restaurant there, he sees Ethel, and immediately tells her of his success and proposes once again. Ethel is tempted to accept him until Thomas Martin, who has involved her in a blackmail operation, threatens to expose her if she marries Carew. Once again brokenhearted, and disgusted with her character, Carew returns to Little Snowbird, only to find that, believing that he would never return, the Indian girl has committed suicide just hours earlier. Before dying, however, she gave birth to their daughter, so Carew determines that he will devote the rest of his life to ...

More Less

Jim Carew, a lighthouse keeper, saves New York socialite Ethel Wyndham from drowning after a boating accident, and falls in love as he nurses her back to health. However, she turns down his marriage proposal because of his working-class status. Despondent, Carew aimlessly leaves the East and ends up prospecting in the Yukon. While striking it rich in Alaska, he begins a romance with an Indian woman, Little Snowbird, but before settling down with her, he decides to take one last look at life in the big city, and returns to New York City. At a restaurant there, he sees Ethel, and immediately tells her of his success and proposes once again. Ethel is tempted to accept him until Thomas Martin, who has involved her in a blackmail operation, threatens to expose her if she marries Carew. Once again brokenhearted, and disgusted with her character, Carew returns to Little Snowbird, only to find that, believing that he would never return, the Indian girl has committed suicide just hours earlier. Before dying, however, she gave birth to their daughter, so Carew determines that he will devote the rest of his life to her.

Less
